title: What are the provisions of Fundamental Rights - Complete Guide?
content: Q: What are the provisions of Fundamental Rights - Complete Guide? A: The Fundamental Rights in India are enshrined in Part III (Articles 12-35) of the Constitution. These rights are essential for the development of human personality and are guaranteed by the Constitution. The six categories of fundamental rights are: 1) Right to Equality (Articles 14-18), 2) Right to Freedom (Articles 19-22), 3) Right against Exploitation (Articles 23-24), 4) Right to Freedom of Religion (Articles 25-28), 5) Cultural and Educational Rights (Articles 29-30), and 6) Right to Constitutional Remedies (Article 32). These rights can be enforced through writ petitions in the Supreme Court under Article 32 or in High Courts under Article 226. The Supreme Court has expanded the scope of these rights through various landmark judgments.
simplified_summary: Q: What are the provisions of Fundamental Rights - Complete Guide? A: The Fundamental Rights in India are enshrined in Part III (Articles 12-35) of the Constitution.  These rights are essential for the development of human personality and are guaranteed by the Constitution.

title: What are the provisions of Article 14 - Equality Before Law?
content: Q: What are the provisions of Article 14 - Equality Before Law? A: Article 14 states: 'The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India.' This article ensures that all persons are equal before the law and are entitled to equal protection of laws. It prohibits discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth. The principle of equality is a fundamental feature of the Indian Constitution and forms the basis of democracy. The Supreme Court has interpreted this article to include the concept of 'reasonable classification' where equals are treated equally and unequals are treated differently based on intelligible differentia.
simplified_summary: Q: What are the provisions of Article 14 - Equality Before Law? A: Article 14 states: 'The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India. ' This article ensures that all persons are equal before the law and are entitled to equal protection of laws.

title: What are the provisions of Article 19 - Freedom of Speech and Expression?
content: Q: What are the provisions of Article 19 - Freedom of Speech and Expression? A: Article 19(1)(a) guarantees the right to freedom of speech and expression to all citizens. This includes the right to express one's views, opinions, and ideas through any medium including print, electronic, and digital media. However, this right is subject to reasonable restrictions under Article 19(2) in the interests of sovereignty and integrity of India, security of the State, friendly relations with foreign States, public order, decency or morality, contempt of court, defamation, or incitement to an offence. The Supreme Court has held that this right includes the right to information, right to criticize government policies, and right to commercial speech.
simplified_summary: However, this right is subject to reasonable restrictions under Article 19(2) in the interests of sovereignty and integrity of India, security of the State, friendly relations with foreign States, public order, decency or morality, contempt of court, defamation, or incitement to an offence.

title: What are the provisions of Article 21 - Right to Life and Personal Liberty?
content: Q: What are the provisions of Article 21 - Right to Life and Personal Liberty? A: Article 21 states: 'No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.' This article has been interpreted broadly by the Supreme Court to include the right to live with human dignity, right to livelihood, right to health, right to education, right to privacy, right to clean environment, and right to die with dignity. It forms the foundation of human rights in India and has been used to expand the scope of fundamental rights through judicial activism. The procedure established by law must be fair, just, and reasonable.
simplified_summary: Q: What are the provisions of Article 21 - Right to Life and Personal Liberty? A: Article 21 states: 'No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law. ' This article has been interpreted broadly by the Supreme Court to include the right to live with human dignity, right to livelihood, right to health, right to education, right to privacy, right to clean environment, and right to die with dignity.

title: What are the provisions of Article 32 - Right to Constitutional Remedies?
content: Q: What are the provisions of Article 32 - Right to Constitutional Remedies? A: Article 32 provides the right to move the Supreme Court for the enforcement of fundamental rights. It is called the 'heart and soul' of the Constitution by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar. The Supreme Court can issue writs like Habeas Corpus (to produce a person), Mandamus (to command public authority), Prohibition (to prevent lower court from exceeding jurisdiction), Certiorari (to quash lower court decision), and Quo Warranto (to question authority of public office holder). This article makes fundamental rights justiciable and enforceable. It is a fundamental right itself and cannot be suspended except during emergency.
simplified_summary: Q: What are the provisions of Article 32 - Right to Constitutional Remedies? A: Article 32 provides the right to move the Supreme Court for the enforcement of fundamental rights.  It is called the 'heart and soul' of the Constitution by Dr.

title: What are the provisions of Writ Petitions - Complete Guide?
content: Q: What are the provisions of Writ Petitions - Complete Guide? A: Writ petitions are formal written applications to a court requesting judicial action. In India, five types of writs are available under Articles 32 and 226: 1) Habeas Corpus - to produce a person before the court and ensure their liberty, 2) Mandamus - to command a public authority to perform its legal duty, 3) Prohibition - to prevent a lower court from exceeding its jurisdiction, 4) Certiorari - to quash the decision of a lower court or tribunal, and 5) Quo Warranto - to question the authority of a person holding a public office. These writs are essential for protecting fundamental rights and ensuring good governance.
simplified_summary: Q: What are the provisions of Writ Petitions - Complete Guide? A: Writ petitions are formal written applications to a court requesting judicial action.  In India, five types of writs are available under Articles 32 and 226: 1) Habeas Corpus - to produce a person before the court and ensure their liberty, 2) Mandamus - to command a public authority to perform its legal duty, 3) Prohibition - to prevent a lower court from exceeding its jurisdiction, 4) Certiorari - to quash the decision of a lower court or tribunal, and 5) Quo Warranto - to question the authority of a person holding a public office.

title: What are the provisions of Criminal Law - IPC Overview?
content: Q: What are the provisions of Criminal Law - IPC Overview? A: The Indian Penal Code (IPC) is the main criminal law of India. It defines various offences and their punishments. Key sections include: Section 299-304 (Culpable Homicide and Murder), Section 307-308 (Attempt to Murder), Section 375-376 (Rape), Section 420 (Cheating), Section 406 (Criminal Breach of Trust), Section 498A (Cruelty by Husband), Section 304B (Dowry Death), and Section 302 (Murder). The IPC is supplemented by various special laws like the Prevention of Corruption Act, Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act, and Information Technology Act.
simplified_summary: It defines various offences and their punishments.

title: What are the provisions of Article 32 - Right to Constitutional Remedies?
content: Q: What are the provisions of Article 32 - Right to Constitutional Remedies? A: Article 32 provides the right to move the Supreme Court for the enforcement of fundamental rights. It is called the 'heart and soul' of the Constitution by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar. The Supreme Court can issue writs like Habeas Corpus, Mandamus, Prohibition, Certiorari, and Quo Warranto for the enforcement of fundamental rights. This article makes fundamental rights justiciable and enforceable.

title: What are the provisions of Culpable Homicide?
content: Q: What are the provisions of Culpable Homicide? A: Whoever causes death by doing an act with the intention of causing death, or with the intention of causing such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, or with the knowledge that he is likely by such act to cause death, commits the offence of culpable homicide. Punishment: Life imprisonment or imprisonment up to 10 years
simplified_summary: Q: What are the provisions of Culpable Homicide? A: Whoever causes death by doing an act with the intention of causing death, or with the intention of causing such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, or with the knowledge that he is likely by such act to cause death, commits the offence of culpable homicide. Punishment: Life imprisonment or imprisonment up to 10 years.

title: What are the provisions of Definition of State?
content: Q: What are the provisions of Definition of State? A: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires, 'the State' includes the Government and Parliament of India and the Government and the Legislature of each of the States and all local or other authorities within the territory of India or under the control of the Government of India.

title: What are the provisions of Laws inconsistent with or in derogation of the fundamental rights?
content: Q: What are the provisions of Laws inconsistent with or in derogation of the fundamental rights? A: All laws in force in the territory of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution, in so far as they are inconsistent with the provisions of this Part, shall, to the extent of such inconsistency, be void. The State shall not make any law which takes away or abridges the rights conferred by this Part and any law made in contravention of this clause shall, to the extent of the contravention, be void.
simplified_summary: Q: What are the provisions of Laws inconsistent with or in derogation of the fundamental rights? A: All laws in force in the territory of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution, in so far as they are inconsistent with the provisions of this Part, shall, to the extent of such inconsistency, be void.  The State shall not make any law which takes away or abridges the rights conferred by this Part and any law made in contravention of this clause shall, to the extent of the contravention, be void.

title: What are the provisions of Prohibition of discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex or place of birth?
content: Q: What are the provisions of Prohibition of discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex or place of birth? A: The State shall not discriminate against any citizen on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth or any of them. No citizen shall, on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth or any of them, be subject to any disability, liability, restriction or condition with regard to access to shops, public restaurants, hotels and places of public entertainment.

title: What are the provisions of Remedies for enforcement of rights conferred by this Part?
content: Q: What are the provisions of Remedies for enforcement of rights conferred by this Part? A: The right to move the Supreme Court by appropriate proceedings for the enforcement of the rights conferred by this Part is guaranteed. The Supreme Court shall have power to issue directions or orders or writs, including writs in the nature of habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto and certiorari, whichever may be appropriate, for the enforcement of any of the rights conferred by this Part.
